title: Defenders dominate BFNL junior netball awards
body_text:
Defenders have stolen the show at the Ballarat Football Netball League junior netball awards with three players who have spent considerable time in the back court awarded for their outstanding seasons.
Subscribe now for unlimited access.
or signup to continue reading
The under-17s winner, East Point's Lily Woodland-Boyanton has spent the majority of her young career to date as a defender and has already tasted action in some of the highest levels in the BFNL.
Woodland-Boyanton finished the count on 25 votes, three ahead of Redan's Elizabeth Morrison, polling four votes in the final two rounds to clinch the win.
"I've always been a defender and all my coaches have always told me to play tough, I've been lucky enough to play against some of the women in the senior ranks, so it's something I'm really proud to bring back to the juniors," she said.
East Point has dominated the under-17s this season having already qualified for the grand final in what is so far an undefeated season.
"It'll be very nerve wracking for us, I think we might end up playing North Ballarat and every time we've played them it's been super close, we just can't wait to get out there."
North Ballarat's Ebony Porter was awarded the MVP in the under-17s for her outstanding year.
In the under-15s it was another win for a defender with Bacchus Marsh's Lucy Phyland-McClure winning a high-scoring count by two votes.
Phyland-McClure finished with 31 votes, two ahead of Mikayla Tito from Darley and Audrey Murnane from North Ballarat. Phyland McClure polled in all but two games on the season and also took out the under-15 netball MVP award.
Phyland-McClure said she had no idea she would poll as well as she did.
"I'm not too sure what stood out about me, I'm really surprised, I didn't know what to expect, I thought it was going to be very tough to get any votes," she said.
"I started as a shooter when I was really young, but I always found it a bit different to play defence. I think there's a lot more pressure on you when you are shooting.
"With the defending I always enjoyed the jumping aspect, it's more about keeping up with your opponent than trying to dodge. I do athletics at school, so I think that's why I enjoy it.
"It's really exciting to win these awards, I never expected anything like this."
Redan's Pippa Edwards was a dominant winner in the under-13s award polling 30 votes t win by eight. Sebastopol's Armani Daws was named the league MVP.
Edwards said she had been happy with the season, but had particularly enjoyed the friendships with her teammates.
"It was lovely playing with the girls I played with," she said. "The whole club was really nice, really supportive and if I dropped my head, they'd always be there to help me get up again and we'd finish strong, it was really good.
"I'm shaking a bit, it's really unexpected to hold this award, I didn't expect it at all. I generally play goal defence, but sometimes I move into centre and get to mix it around."
